NAME
POSITION TITLE
Kenneth W. Trevorrow
Research Fellow
EDUCATION
INSTITUTION AND LOCATION
DEGREE
YEAR CONFERRED
FIELD OF STUDY
Univ. of Miami, Coral Gables, FL
B.S.
1981
Biol./Chemistry
Univ. of Miami School of Medicine, Miami, FL
Ph.D.
1988
Pharmacology
Max-Planck Inst. for Biochemistry, Munich, Germany
Postdoc
1988-90
Mol. Biol/Cancer
Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Boston, MA
Postdoc
1990
Mol. Biol/Cancer
UT Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas
Postdoc
1990-Cur.
Mol. Biology
Professional Experience:
2/88-2/90
Fellow-German/American Cooperative Project in Cancer Research. Mildred- School-Labor Max Planck Institute for Biochemistry, Martinsried, West Germany. Biochemical mechanisms involved in multiple drug resistance mediated by mdr1 in leukemia.
2/90-12/90
Research Fellow in Pathology, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts. Cloning and expression of the bone morphogenetic protein BMP-2b.
11/90-Present
Research Fellow, Department of Biochemistry, University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, Texas. Gene expression and chromatin structure of the immunoglobulin Kappa light chain gene.
Publications
Blasquez, V.C., Hale, M.A., Trevorrow, K.W., and Garrard, W.T. (1992) Immunoglobulin K Gene Enhancers Synergistically Activate Gene Expression but Independently Determine Chromatin Structure. J. Biol. Chem. 267, 23888-23893.
Trevorrow, K., Lamidis, T., Valet, G. (1991) Carboxylic Ionophores Increase Rhodamine 123 Retention in Multidrug-Resistant Friend Leukemia Cells with Increased mdr1 Gene Expression. J.Cell, Pharmacol. 2:217-224.
Trevorrow, K.W., Lampidis, T.J., and Valet, G. (1989) The Effect of Depletion of Glutathione on the Toxicity of Doxorubicin in Friend Leukemia Cells with Acquired REsistance as Measured with Multiparameter Flow Cytometry. Proceedings of the 1989 Meeting of the European Society for Clinical and Experimental Cytology. Elmau, West Germany.
Lampidis, T.J., Savaraj, N., Valet, G.K., Trevorrow, K.W., Fourcade, A. and Tapiero, H. (1989) Relationship of Chemical Charge of Anti-Cancer Agents to Increased Accumulation and Cytotoxicity in Cardiac and Tumor Cells: Relevance to Multi-Drug Resistance in Interface of Clinical and Laboratory Responses to Anticancer Drugs, Eds. H. Tapiero, J. Robert and T. Lampidis. John Libbey Publishers, London.
Lampidis, T., Castello, C., Giglio, A., Pressman, B., Viallet, P., Trevorrow. K.W., Valet, G., Tapiero, H., and Savaraj, N. (1989) Relevance of the Electrical Charge of Rhodamine Dyes to Multiple Drug Resistance. Biochem, Pharmac, 38: 4267-4271.
Hasmann, M., Valet, G., Tapiero, H., Trevorrow, K.W., Lampidis, T. (1989) Membrane Potential Differences Between Adriamycin Sensitive and Resistant Cells as Measured by Flow Cytometry. Biochem, Pharmacol. 38 (2): 305-312.
